Toronto Mayor John Tory has announced plans to increase the police budget by almost $50 million for 2023.
Michael Finlay, a longtime former CBC Radio journalist, died from medical complications a week after a random assault on a Danforth Avenue sidewalk.
In December 2022, Shopify confirmed that it no longer intended to expand to massive new Toronto office space, citing shift toward remote-first.

In December 2022, the Senate unanimously approved legislation that would ban the use of TikTok on government phones and devices as part of the push to combat security concerns related to the Chinese-owned social media company.
In September 2022, President Biden declared the coronavirus pandemic “over” in an interview.
In November 2022, the Biden administration announced that it would stop accepting student loan forgiveness applications after a federal judge ruled against the program.
In 2022, a Connecticut jury ordered Infowars host Alex Jones to pay nearly $1 billion in damages to the family of victims of the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting.
In September 2022, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention no longer recommended universal masking in health care settings, unless the facilities are in areas of high COVID-19 transmission.

In 2022, the Department of Defense (DOD) said that it will allow its networks to access abortion-related websites, permitting military and civilian personnel to access those sites on the agency’s computers.

In June 2022, a bipartisan group of 20 senators led by Sens. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) and John Cornyn (R-Texas) announced they have agreed to “a commonsense proposal” to curb gun violence in response to the mass shooting in Uvalde, Texas, that left 21 people dead at Robb Elementary School.
In June 2022, the Supreme Court struck down Roe v. Wade, eliminating the nearly 50-year-old constitutional right to abortion and handing states authority to drastically limit or ban the procedure.
In Nov 2021, Salvador announced that the cancellation of public New Year's Eve parties in the city. The cities of Florianópolis and Belo Horizonte had already made a similar decision.
In 2021, according to the IBGE (Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics), the total number of favelas in Brazil had more than doubled in the last decade, jumping from 6,329 to 13,151.

Marília Mendonça, who became the most listened to singer in the country when she pioneered a musical genre recognized for the machismo of its lyrics, died in a plane crash in Minas Gerais. She was 26 years old.
In Dec 2021, Grupo Itapemirim announced that it temporarily suspended the operations of its airline, ITA (Itapemirim Transportes Aéreos), for an internal restructuring.
The Civil Police of Rio launched an operation to arrest suspects involved in the death of three boys who disappeared in the Castelar community, in Belford Roxo (RJ), in 2020.

In 2022, the Ministry of Women, Family and Human Rights, headed by Damares Alves, produced a technical note, forwarded to other ministries, in which it opposes the vaccine passport and the mandatory application of pediatric doses against Covid.
In 2022, the municipality of Marabá, in the southeast of Pará, faced the biggest floods of the last 20 years in the region.
In the opening words of his private meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin, Jair Bolsonaro said that "we are in solidarity with Russia."
In 2022, a five-year-old Brazilian boy was recognized as the youngest person in the world to identify an asteroid.
Luiz Antônio Bizarro, the singer, producer and composer from São Paulo died at age 73.
Education Minister Milton Ribeiro was dismissed after suspicions of corruption with MEC Business Desk.

In his first meeting with the international press, at Palácio de la Moneda, in Santiago, the newly sworn-in president of Chile, Gabriel Boric, stated that he wants to have a good relationship with Brazil.
Accused of racism against Corinthians fans, Argentine trader Leonardo Ponzo, 42, did not even pay the R$3,000 bail imposed on him. The Argentine consulate paid the amount to São Paulo.

The businessman and billionaire Jorge Paulo Lemann said in a debate at the Brazil Conference that "We have an election going on in Brazil and we will have a new president. My basic objective in Brazil is to try to improve education. We are preparing a new kit on how to improve education in Brazil, which I think Brazil needs most."
US President Joe Biden and Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro attended a bilateral meeting at the 9th Summit of the Americas in Los Angeles, California, June 9, 2022.
In June 2022, former Bolivian President rejected Jair Bolsonaro's offer for asylum in Brazil.
In July 2022, a Bolsonaro federal criminal police officer invaded a birthday party and shot and killed PT member Marcelo Aloizio de Arruda in Foz do Iguaçu.
The Brazilian Army withdrew from participating in the 2022 International Army Games organized by Russia.
Investment by Chinese companies in Brazil more than tripled in 2021, returning to pre-Covid pandemic levels.

On social media, President Jair Bolsonaro called Queen Elizabeth II "an extraordinary and unique woman, whose example of leadership, humility, and love for her country will continue to inspire us and the whole world until the end of time."
In 2022, Argentine police arrested a man who allegedly tried to fire a pistol at Vice President Cristina Kirchner as she arrived home in the Recoleta neighborhood of Buenos Aires.
Bolsonarist federal deputy Carla Zambelli pulled out a gun and pointed it at people on a Saturday of Oct 2022, in São Paulo.
Thaynã Higor, 25, a three-time world champion in jiu-jitsu, was shot in the head in front of a restaurant in Praia Grande, on the coast of São Paulo.

In 2022, singer-songwriter Gilberto Gil, 80 years old, and his wife Flora Gil, 62 years old, were harassed by Brazilian fans in Qatar, as they walked down a corridor to watch the match between Brazil and Serbia at the Lusail stadium.

In 2022, Katiuscia Torres Soares, 34, known as Kat Torres or Kat A Luz, was arrested in Minas Gerais on suspicion of keeping people in conditions analogous to slavery in the United States, among other possible crimes.
Germany’s finance minister Christian Lindner rejected EU plans for a de facto ban on the sale of new combustion engines cars by 2035.

In 2022, TikTok abandoned plans to expand its live ecommerce initiative in Europe and the US, after the social media platform’s foray into QVC-style shopping in the UK was hit by internal problems and struggled to gain traction with consumers.
French couple Christel and Luc Fockaert won legal fight and were awarded €110,000 after over health problems they claim were caused by windfarm.
In Oct 2021, Cambridge University halted £400m deal with UAE over Pegasus spyware claims.
In Dec 2021, European Union foreign ministers agreed to slap sanctions on targets linked to the Russian private military company Wagner, accused of acting to destabilize Ukraine and parts of Africa.
In Dec 2021, Russia’s Supreme Court ordered the shuttering of Memorial, Russia’s oldest human rights watchdog, for repeatedly violating the country’s foreign agent law.
In Nov 2021, U.S. Central Intelligence Agency director William Burns met the head of Russia's powerful Security Council for talks in Moscow.
Nikolai Romanov, a Covid-denying rogue Russian monk who barricaded himself in a monastery last year with dozens of followers was sentenced to 3.5 years in prison in Nov 2021.
In Dec 2021, Russian President Vladimir Putin said that the conflict in eastern Ukraine between Kiev's army and pro-Russian separatists "looks like genocide,"
In Feb 2022, Russia’s State Duma backed a resolution calling for diplomatic recognition of Eastern Ukraine’s pro-Russian Donbas People’s Republics.
In Feb 2022, Russia expelled the United States' deputy chief of mission to Moscow at the height of bilateral tensions over the Ukraine crisis.

Russian President Vladimir Putin said he was ready for compromise and would look at proposals put forward by French leader Emmanuel Macron during talks in Feb 2022, while still blaming the West for raising tensions over Ukraine.
Russian forces bombarded Ukraine's capital during a visit by UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres.

In May 2022, Russian President Vladimir Putin lashed out at Western countries and hailed Russian soldiers fighting in Ukraine as he addressed an annual military parade in Moscow that marks the Soviet Union’s defeat of Nazi Germany.
Russian President Vladimir Putin did not attend the funeral of the last Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev.
In 2022, a Russian court found U.S. basketball star Brittney Griner guilty of smuggling and storing drugs and sentenced her to nine years in prison.
In 2022, Kremlin critic Andrei Pivovarov, the former head of pro-democracy group Open Russia, was sentenced to four years in prison on charges of “undesirable” activities.
In June 2022, Russia said it was blacklisting 49 UK citizens, including defense officials and prominent journalists and editors from the BBC, The Financial Times and The Guardian.
In 2022, a Russian court sentenced Moscow municipal deputy Alexei Gorinov to seven years in prison under censorship laws that criminalize anti-war protests.
Between March and July of 2022, China spent $35 billion on Russian oil, gas and coal compared with $20 billion the same time the year before.
In 2022, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed off on the annexation of four partially occupied Ukrainian regions.
In Oct 2022, President Volodymyr Zelensky accused Russia of planting mines at a hydroelectric dam in the Kherson region of southern Ukraine.
A city of around 630,000 people, Izhevsk is the regional capital of Russia's Udmurt Republic, located around 1,000 kilometers (620 miles) east of Moscow.
A total of 63 Russian soldiers were killed in a Ukrainian attack on a vocational school in Russian-occupied eastern Ukraine that took place in the early hours of New Year’s Day 2023.
In Jan 2023, Army General Valery Gerasimov, Chief of the General Staff of the Russian armed forces, was appointed Commander of the Joint Grouping of Troops.
